results.title: American movie [NTSC]
results.creator_credit: Northwestern Movie Company, LLC, Chris Smith and Sarah Price
results.brief_description: Winner of the Grand Jury Prize at the 1999 Sundance Film Festival, “American Movie” is a hilarious, engrossing portrait of wannabe filmmaker Mark Borchardt. The highly vocal, quirky, 30-year-old Mark lives at home with his parents in Milwaukee, Wisconsin, getting by on a few odd jobs like newspaper delivery and shovelling snow whilst his 3 kids live with his ex-wife. Mark’s big dream, however, is to be an American filmmaker. A horror film buff, he has been making no-budget gore flicks on 8mm since an early age, all of which starred his friends and some of which include sequels that run up to the fourth instalment. Not much has changed: Mark is still enlisting the help of friends and family to make creepy, gore-filled, horror films. Filmmakers Chris Smith and Sarah Price follow Mark on a two-year journey as he goes from commencing and then aborting plans for his feature project “Northwestern” to completing what he hopes will be his breakthrough film, “Coven”, a 30-minute no-budget horror. The gap between Mark’s suburban reality and his dream is all too obvious, and the filmmakers milk a lot of laughs from his ‘loser’ existence: his drugged out friend, Mike; his relationship with Uncle Bill, a senile old man from whom he derives financing; his home life; his eccentric personality; the ‘nobodies’ who help him on his film and so on. But the documentary also shows a great deal of compassion for Mark and recognition of both his earnestness to make films and the many hurdles and obstacles this dream involves. Above all, “American Movie” is a testament to the contemporary cultural phenomenon specific to the MTV generation: the desire to be rid of a dreaded anonymous suburban existence and to be famous, to be somebody, if just for one day.

results.title: American Indians of today
results.brief_description: Surveys the life of American Indians in the United States today. Home for most Indians is on a reservation, where they may be engaged in farming or cattle raising. Some tribes have found it difficult to adapt themselves after centuries of semi-nomadic life. Other tribes have advanced to local self-government. Includes scenes of life on the San Carlos Apache Reservation in Arizona, the Sioux in South Dakota, the Seneca in New York.

results.title: American beauty [DVD]
results.creator_credit: Cohen, NBCUniversal, Jinks, Bruce Cohen, Dan Jinks and Sam Mendes
results.brief_description: Director Sam Mendes makes his feature film debut with this film about the dark side of an American family and the nature and cost of beauty in a culture obsessed with outward appearances. Kevin Spacey plays Lester Burnham, a man in his mid-40s going through an intense mid-life crisis. His relationship with his wife Caroline (Annette Bening) is not a warm one - on the surface she is in full control of her life, inside she feels empty and desolate. Their teenage daughter Jane (Thora Birch) is depressed and has a chronic lack of self-esteem. Lester falls into uncontrollable lust with Jane’s beautiful best friend Angela (Mena Suvari) and she becomes part of a drastic plan to change his body and his life. Meanwhile, their new next-door neighbor, Colonel Fitts (Chris Cooper) has spent a lifetime in the Marine Corps and can tolerate no other way of life, which makes things very difficult for his son Ricky, an aspiring filmmaker and part-time drug dealer who is obsessed with beauty, wherever and whatever it may be. This film is a darkly humourous, scathing and shocking journey through life in suburban America. (Awards: Academy Awards for Best Film, Best Director, Best Actor 1999)

results.title: American Ballet Theatre in San Francisco
results.creator_credit: National Video Corporation, Robin Scott and Brian Large
results.brief_description: This is a companion piece to “American Ballet Theatre at the Met” and features five short ballets including two pas de deaux performed by the American Ballet Theater at the War Memorial Opera House, San Francisco with the San Francisco Opera Orchestra on 1st March 1985. Artistic director: Mikhail Baryshnikov. Airs: Music by George Frideric Handel, choreography by Paul Taylor, conducted by Paul Connelly and featuring dancers Peter Fonseca, Johan Renvall, Lisa Rinehart. Jardin aux lilas (Lilac garden): Music by Ernest Chausson, choreography by Antony Tudor, conducted by Alan Barker and featuring dancers Leslie Browne, Martine Van Hamel, Robert La Fosse, Michael Owen. The Black swan from Swan Lake (Act III): Pas de deaux. Music by Piotr Ilyich Tchaikovsky, choreography by Marius Petipa, conducted by Alan Barker and featuring dancers Cynthia Gregory, Fernando Bujones. Romeo and Juliet - Balcony pas de deux (Act I): Music by Sergei Prokofiev, choreography by Kenneth MacMillan, conducted by Alan Barker and featuring dancers Natalia Makarova, Kevin McKenzie. Great galloping Gottschalk: Music by Louis Moreau Gottschalk, choreography by Lynne Taylor-Corbett, conducted by Paul Connelly and featuring dancers Susan Jaffe, Robert La Fosse.

results.title: American Ballet Theatre at the Met
results.creator_credit: National Video Corporation and Brian Large
results.brief_description: These three wonderful ballets plus a pas de deux were performed by the American Ballet Theater at the Metropolitan Opera House, New York, on 11 June 1984. Les Sylphides: Music by Frideric Chopin, choreography by Michel Fokine, conducted by Paul Connelly and featuring dancers Mikhail Baryshnikov, Cynthia Harvey, Marianna Tcherkassky, Cheryl Yeager. Sylvia: Music by Leo Delibes, choreography by George Balanchine, conducted by Alan Barker and featuring dancers Patrick Bissell, Martina Van Hamel. Triad: Music by Serge Prokofiev, choreography by Kenneth MacMillan, conducted by Alan Barker with violin solo by Dennis Cleveland and featuring dancers Robert La Fosse, Amanda McKerrow, Johan Renvall. Paquita: Music by Ludwig Minkus, choreography by Natalia Makarova, conducted by Paul Connelly and featuring dancers Fernando Bujones, Cynthia Gregory.

results.title: America: from Hitler to M-X
results.creator_credit: Parallel Films, Fourth Wall Repertory, Albee Gordon, Ralph Klein, Saul Newton and Joan Harvey
results.brief_description: A striking film statement about the military aims of the United States today; its longstanding first strike policy, and the escalating threat of worldwide annihilation. Here is an expose of America’s top level corporate and banking links with fascism for over sixty years. The film indicts the United States as aggressor in today’s international move to war

results.title: America wide
results.brief_description: This multi-media presentation contains thousands of images of America (taken across all 50 states) as photographed by Australian Ken Duncan. The stunning panoramic images convey the diversity of the landscape and the beauty of nature. The images are accompanied by music composed by Andy Sorenson, with eleven separate tracks. Also includes the piece Song for America by Kathy Johnston.

results.title: America screams
results.brief_description: Discover the history of amusement and theme parks in America, the design and construction of roller coasters, the invention of the “hot dog” and experience, graphically, some of those most amazing roller coaster rides for yourself. Hosted by Vincent Price, this video details the history of amusement parks from the establishment of Coney Island (New York) in the 1860s with its three separate parks, Steeplechase Park, Dreamland and Luna Park to a point when by the 1920s, there were around 1,000 amusement parks throughout America. Meet John Allen, the designer of the wooden roller coaster and see how today’s monster thrill rides (longer, faster and higher) are conceived, from the artist’s design through to models, prototypes and the final ride. Also includes footage of the original Disneyland, (first of the “theme” parks) and Palisades Park.

results.title: America on the edge of abundance
results.brief_description: Traces America’s snowballing history as an affluent society and looks at the dilemma which abundance brings. A land of abounding factory production and consumption, where success is measured by material standards. America underwent a revolution from an agricultural to an manufacturing society. Now a second revolution looms, to an automated society. What will this mean to the nation, and how individuals will accept a society in which a minority of people can manage the nation’s work, is discussed.

results.title: America in Vietnam
results.creator_credit: Information Television Productions, Cinequity Funding, Ian Macleod, Ron Kelly, Paul Lang and Don North
results.brief_description: A preview of the series “Vietnam: the ten thousand day war”, covering America’s shifting motivations and priorities during three decades of the Vietnam conflict. The conflict became America’s longest, costliest, and most mysterious war and involved five presidencies. Written by Pulitzer Prize winner, Peter Arnett and narrated by Richard Basehart.
